components.description:
A cartoon-styled representation of dizziness. Generally depicted as one or more yellow stars swirling in a yellow or blue circle.

Resembles squeans, stylized stars and circles over the heads of characters in comics and animation to show they are dizzy, disoriented, intoxicated, or sick.

Commonly used for emphasis and flair or to indicate various positive sentiments. Like üå† Shooting Star, sometimes used as a visual reference to NBC’s More You Know public service announcement, popular in the 1990s and featuring a shooting star logo.

Not to be confused with ‚≠ê Star, üåü Glowing Star, and ‚ú® Sparkles, though their applications may overlap.

Facebook’s design features two stars spinning along two intersecting purple circles, though it previously only featured one yellow ring. Samsung’s design previously displayed several yellow circles and stars.
components.title: Dizzy Symbol

title: Dizzy Symbol

version.description:
Released in October 2010, Unicode 6.0 was the first version of the Unicode Standard to support emoji.

Some characters in prior versions of Unicode were retroactively updated to provide an emoji presentation. This release was the first to introduce new characters for the sole purpose of compatability with emojis being used in Japan.

emoji_net_data.category: Miscellaneous Symbols And Pictographs -> Comic style symbols
emoji_net_data.definition: A symbol used in comics or other visual mediums, indicating that a person is dizzy. This is usually shown as a circle of stars surrounding t http://emojipedia.org/dizzy-symbol/
emoji_net_data.name: dizzy

bn:00105808a: Indicating the most important performer or role

bn:00101649a: Dizzy, feeling dizzy or unsteady and as if about to fall down.
Having or causing a whirling sensation; liable to falling
Having a sensation of whirling, with a tendency to fall; giddy; feeling unbalanced or lightheaded.
Having a sensation of turning around.
Having a sensation of whirling and a tendency to fall.

bn:00099543a: Possessing or using or characteristic of or appropriate to supernatural powers- Shakespeare

bn:00094295v: Be the star in a performance

bn:13692524v: To produce, transform (something), (as if) by magic.
To produce something, as if by magic.

bn:00073964n: Sphere of plasma held together by gravity, undergoing fusion
A luminous celestial body that is made from gases (particularly hydrogen and helium) and forms the shape of a sphere.
This article is for quotes about stars, or which make prominent mention of stars.
(astronomy) a celestial body of hot gases that radiates energy derived from thermonuclear reactions in the interior
A star is a massive, luminous sphere of plasma held together by its own gravity.
A luminous celestial body, made up of plasma (particularly hydrogen and helium) and having a spherical shape. Depending on context the sun may or may not be included.

bn:00072016n: The Sky is the portion of outer space or the atmosphere visible from a position within a world.
Everything that is above the surface of the Earth.
The atmosphere above a given point, especially as visible from the ground during the day.
The sky is everything that lies above the surface of the Earth, including the atmosphere and outer space.
The atmosphere and outer space as viewed from the earth
The part of the earth's atmosphere and space outside it that is visible from earth's surface. During the day it is perceived as blue, and at night as black.

bn:00052688n: The use of rituals or actions, especially based on supernatural or occult knowledge, to manipulate or obtain information about the natural world, especially when seen as falling outside the realm of religion; also the forces allegedly drawn on for such practices.
Any art that invokes supernatural powers
Magic or sorcery is an attempt to understand, experience and influence the world using rituals, symbols, actions, gestures and language.
Thaumaturgy is the capability of a magician or a saint to work magic or miracles.
Ritual associated with supernatural magic or mysticism.

The use of rituals or actions, especially based on supernatural or occult knowledge, to manipulate or obtain information about the natural world, especially when seen as falling outside the realm of religion; also the forces allegedly drawn on for such practices. A specific ritual or procedure associated with supernatural magic or with mysticism; a spell.
The use of paranormal methods to manipulate natural forces (e.g., witchcraft)

bn:00027951n: Vertigo is a subtype of dizziness in which a patient inappropriately experiences the perception of motion due to dysfunction of the vestibular system.
The state of being dizzy; the sensation of instability.
The state of being off balance
A sensation of irregular or whirling motion, either of oneself or of external objects.
Dizziness is an impairment in spatial perception and stability.
Lightheadedness is a common and typically unpleasant sensation of dizziness and/or a feeling that one may faint.
A sensation of whirling and loss of balance, caused by looking down from a great height or by disease affecting the inner ear.
Vertigo is a 1958 film about a San Francisco detective and his psychological troubles with a fear of heights and an obsession over a woman.
A reeling sensation; a feeling that you are about to fall

bn:00054599n: A streak of light in the sky at night that results when a meteoroid hits the earth's atmosphere and air friction causes the meteoroid to melt or vaporize or explode
A meteor, especially a streak of light in the night sky, caused by a meteoroid burning up as it enters the Earth's atmosphere.
A fast-moving streak of light in the night sky caused by the entry of extraterrestrial matter into the earth's atmosphere: A shooting star or falling star.
A streak of light in the sky at night that results when a meteoroid hits the earth's atmosphere.
